listWit.witness: London, British Museum Royal 10 A I

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of this text has followed the recommendations of the LombardPress 1.0.0 guidelines for a critical edition.

change.p: File Started for the first time.

div.head: Concerning the text
div.p:
Nunc de veritate sive proprietate Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 1 [n.1], (I, 95, ll. 4).
etc. This is distinction 8. To the preceding it is continued thus because after the Master showed that in the divine there is true generation, now in this distinction he puts a multitude of properties signifying its perfection. Et this is divided into three parts because in the first place the Master makes determinations about the eternal being of God, in the second place about his unchangeability, in the third place about his simplicity. The second begins at
deus in solius essentia Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 2 [n.1], (I, 97, ll.2). , the third at
eademque Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 3 [n.1], (I, 98, ll. 20). . The first is in three parts, for in the first place he shows how this name being or essence is proper to God, in the second place from what has been said is introduces a doubt, and in the third place he responds to it. The second begins at
hic diligenter Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 1 [n.4], (I, 95, ll. 21-22). . The third begins at
illud ergo quod Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 1 [n.6], (I, 96, ll. 20). . The second principal part is undivided, but the third is divided into two parts because in the first place the Master shows the simplicity of the divine nature through comparison and external relations, in the second place through internal relation. The second begins at
hic diligenter
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 5 [n.1], (XXX).
. And this is the division of the present distinction.

div.head: Question
div.p: Whether the first cause of a producibile being alone is simple, necessary, and unchangeable or invariable?

div.head: Rationes principales
div.p: That not, there is some creature that is indivisibly simple, therefore etc. The antecedent is proved then because to every specific grade of some thing there corresponds a punctual or indivisible being. This is clear because, whenever something grade is added or subtracted no matter how small, the thing does not remain in the same species, therefore such a thing is indivisible.

In the second place, there something below the first cause that is necessary, therefore. The antecedent is clear because through
the Holy Doctor Contra Gentiles, book two, chapter 29 , where from what has been said
therefore that in which there is not matter, or, if there is, there is not potentaility for another form, does not have the potency for non being, therefore such things are absolutely necessary
Aquinas, Summa contra gentiles, II, c. 29 (13, 335). . But it is certain that an neither an angel nor a a soul has matter, therefore. This is confirmed because an angel and a soul do not have within them a principle leading them to non being, therefore they have no potency for non being, therefore they are necessary.

In the third place, in the first cause there is an absolute modal distinction and a conceptual or virtual distinction, therefore. The antecedent for the first part is from
James of Viterbo Iacobus de Viterbo, XXX
and for the second part is from
Alphonsus, distinction eight of book one, article two, conclusion four Alphonsus Toletanus Vargas, I, d. 8, a. 1, conc. 4 . The consequences is clear because any such distinction is repugnant to the highest simplicity.

In opposition is the opinion of the
Master in this distinction Lombardus, Sent. I, d.8, c. 3 (I, 98) et 6, (I, 100). . Again the
Apostle in I Timothy 6
says says that
God alone has immortality I Timotheum 6:16 . Again Augustine III De Trinitate says
God alone does not change and is not able to change Augustinus, De Trinitate, III, XXX .

div.head: First conclusion
div.p: The first conclusion: it is as necessary that the first cause is as it is that a creature is able to be. This is proved because inasmuch as it is necessary that God is God and is omnipotent, by as much necessity he is externally productive, and by as much necessity is something external able to be produced and is able to have being, therefore etc.

This is confirmed because, if the first cause were not able to produce anything outside itself, it would seem that from the fact that something is producible it would be produced, but this is impossible. Nor does this seem to be a problem because it would still be able to corrupt this whole and then recreate it, therefore.

First corollary: thought it is not the case that a creature is not able not to be, nevertheless if the first cause were to act outside itself through the mode of nature, then it would be necessary for some producible thing to be. The first part is clear because some created thing is contingently produced by and in conserved in its being. The second part is clear because, if one thing were produced and not another thing, then either this would be because it would were determined that this thing be produced and not the other, and not this because this is to produce freely since one is equally as possible as the other, or this would be because one thing would be able to be produced and not the other, but this is not the case because then it would be producible and not producibile.

Second corollary: if the first cause were to act outside itself necessarily and naturally, all producibile and corruptibile things would be produced and corrupted at the same time and equally. This is clear because if a fire itself were able to produce b heat and corrupt b heat, it would produce and corrupt at the same time. Therefore, since the first cause alone is able with another it is able in the genus of an efficient cause, the proposed follows that if it were to act naturally, etc.

Third corollary: it is not stand that the first cause is productive of every producible creature and to this to act outside of itself from the necessity of nature. This is clear to this that to produce naturally, it would follows that all producible things are produced and corrupted at the same time and equally. But this implies a contradiction, therefore.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p:
The second conclusion: though only three supposites are distinguished in the one super simple essence, nevertheless this is not properly called diversity or difference. The first part is clear through faith because there is one Father, another Son, and another Holy Spirit, therefore only three supposites are distinguished in the divine essence. This is confirmed because a distinction or difference is nothing, therefore the should not be put in God. This is clear because whatever is in God is something. The antecedent is clear because if only God and man were to exists and nothing else, God and man would still be different, therefore distinction or difference are nothing something or somethings. For this
conclusion there is the reasoning
Augustine VI De Trinitate, chapter 4, de magnis Augustinus, De Trinitate, VI, c. 4
and
chapter 14, de parvis Augustinus, De Trinitate, VI, c. 14 . From the second part of the conclusion, it follows that though it would be said truly and properly that some things are distinguished in reality, and in intention, and in reason, nevertheless it is not properly said that this distinct is intentional, real, or of reason. This is clear because a distinction is nothing, therefore it is not. The consequence is clear because what is absolutely nothing does not exists

First corollary: every perfection which God really is some perfection of God formally. This is clear because, if the divine perfections in some mode differed or were different, it would follow that the divine supposites would not differ only in the divine essence. The consequence is clear in
the first part of the second conclusion Vide supra .

Second corollary: that just among divine perfections there is no formal distinction, so also are a distinction of reason or modal distinction repugnant to them Or thus, just as it does not stand that the divine perfections are distinguished formally, so it is also repugnant for them to be distinguished by reason or formally. This is clear because otherwise in them there would not be the highest simplicity and indifference.

Third corollary: just as it is repugnant that there are a plurality of Gods, so it is repugnant that there are a formal diversity of perfections in God. This is clear because, if such a plurality of formalities in God were possible, it follows that there is something which is absolutely formally God which is not every God. Again, it would follow that something would be God really which is merely contingent, but this is as repugnant as it is that there are many gods, therefore. The first consequence is proved because if divine justice is God formally, then the divine wisdom, if it is formally not justice, then it will not be God formally. The second consequence is clear because the fact that God wants to beatify Peter is really God, and nevertheless by positing formalities of this type God is contingently.

These three corollaries seem to be from the mind of Anselm in the Monologion chapter 17 who says
whatever is said essentially about the highest essence, thus this is in one consideration essentially one. For since some man is said to be a body, rational, and man, he is not in any mode or consideration said to be three things. Thus truly the highest divine essence is in no way said in such a way that it is not this same thing according to consideration and according to another Anselmus, Monologion, 17, (I, 31, ll. 25-32) . From this these corollary seem to be clear.

div.head: Third conclusion
div.p:
Third conclusion: just as the first cause alone has every perfection absolutely and is including itself, so also is it formally and completely lacking any kind of compositions and excluding from itself. The first part is proved because according to Anselm God is
that which nothing greater or better is able to be thought Anselmus, Proslogion 3 (I, 103, ll. 1-2) . The second part is because simplicity should be placed before composition according to
Augustine De quantitate animae, chapter 12 Augustinus, De quantitate, XXX , ergo, But the first cause alone is of the highest simplicity. This is clear indivisibility, immutability, and per se actuality belong to the ratio of simplicity, but these things suit God alone and are not able to be found in a creature.

The first corollary: any species either of a given or giveable form are perfectly confluibile into a superior form or species. This is clear because no such species is unchangeable in its being, therefore God is able to make it that flow together in a unified way into something superior.

The second corollary: it is not the case that some individual depends on a first cause and unitively contains every degree of perfection. This is clear because then such an individual would not be able flow unitively with another individual into a superior species or into some more perfect individual.

The third corollary: it is not the case for some individual that it is repugnant that some dependent created being is not able to be subjectively under some accident and that it is repugnant that this created thing truly is able to unitively contain every grade of simplicity. This is clear because non individual of any given
or giveable species is able to be so simple that it is not able to be the subject of an elicited act or the subject of some habit infused by God, therefore. The antecedent is clear because simplicity of this type suits God alone. From what has been said the affirmative part of the conclusion follows.

div.head: Obiectiones et Responsiones
div.p: Against the first conclusion and its corollaries: something other than God is necessary, therefore. The antecedent is proved because the divine perfection goes out to what is produced similar to itself to the degree that is not repugnant to the creature. But to be necessary is not repugnant to a creature, therefore the divine goodness produces the creatures in this way. The major premise is known. The minor premise is clear because, if it were repugnant to the creature to be necessary, then it would seem to be by virtue of the fact that it comes from another. But this is not the case because the Son has his being from another, and nevertheless it does not have this being contingently, therefore.

In the second place, if an angel or the soul were able not to be, then this would be because God withdrew his influence from them. But this is impossible because this would mean his goodness had changed, therefore such things are not able to be.

In the third place: substances separated from matter do not have a passive potency for privation or corruption, therefore they are not able not to be. The consequence holds since matter is the ratio maintenance and corruption in creatures. These are the arguments of the Holy Doctor, in the place it was noted earlier at the beginning of the question.

In the fourth place: because either for something to be necessary it corresponds precisely either that it is punctual or quantitive. If the first, then it is not of immense perfection. If the second, then it is able to be imagined in this species to be more or less necessary since it is possible to everything something less, so it is possible to give to this necessity less quantity, and thus many things will be necessary.

In the fifth place: if the entire line of producbile things were contingent with respect to being and non being, it follows that the whole would be able to be put completely into being. The consequent is false through what has been said because the first cause would not be able to act outside itself. The consequence is clear because the whole is able not to be as
the first corollary Vide supra
says.

In the sixth place: no individual of an inferior species is able to contain the total perfection of its species, therefore it is necessary that one thing is not able to contain the total breadth of necessity, therefore there is not only one thing in that species. The antecedent is clear through the
second corollary of the third conclusion Vide supra , and the consequences are clear.
This is confirmed because to be, as the proposition man is an animal signified, is necessary being, therefore there are many necessary beings. The consequence holds because this is not God..

Again, to this proposition nothing is, a contradiction does not follow, there this is able to be true, therefore nothing is necessary to be necessary. The consequences holds, and the antecedent is proved because to no negative does an affirmative follow, therefore neither does some contradiction because every contradiction is composed from an affirmative and negative or at least includes one.

Against the second conclusion: in the first place it is argued the authority the Damascene, in book one, chapter three, where he says
Whatever we say about God affirmatively does not show his nature but those things, which are about his nature. For if you say he is good, if just, and if wise, and anything else, you do not speak his nature.
Ioannes Damescenus, I, c. 4, (PG 94.799BC); Burgundionis versio 4,5, p. 21, 41-45)

Contra primum corollarium: si Deus esset immense simplex, aut divisibiliter aut indivisibiliter. Non primum quia tunc haberet partes. Nec secundum quia tunc solum per indivisibilem staret a nihilo, et sic infinite minus distaret divina essentia angelo quam quaecumque creatura, quod est falsum.
Secundo: sapientia in communi non est iustitia in communi, ergo ne infinita sapientia infinita iustitia. Tenet consequentia quia infinitas non tollit rationem propriam alicuius rei, ut videtur.

Contra secundum corollarium: illa quae non sunt synonyma significant diversas res vel eandem diversis rationibus, sed bonitas et iustitia, misericordia et aeternitas non sunt synonyma, ideo ergo sed non
significant diversas res, ergo diversos modos. Ergo in Deo est distinctio modalis
Iacobus de Viterbio quodlibet tertio, quaestione septima Iacobus de Viterbio, Quodlibet III, q. 7, 2, XXX .

Secundo sequitur quod volitiva divina formaliter esset intellectiva divina et econverso. Consequens est falsum quia tunc, quidquid esset obiectum, unus esset obiectum alterius modo. Hoc est falsum, quia deus intelligit malum culpae quod tamen nullo modo vult

Tertia: illa quae necessitat intellectum ad actus distinctos essentialiter secundum rationem vel conceptibiliter distinguitur, sed perfectiones divinae necessitant ad actus distinctos essentialiter intellectum, ergo huiusmodi perfectiones divinae conceptibiliter seu virtualiter sunt distinctae. Maior patet ubi una res necessitat ad actus distinctos essentialiter facit illud idem quod facerent
s
res diversae realiter distinctae. Minor patet quia sapientia divina necessitat intellectum ad conceptum sapientiae et bonitas ad conceptum bonitatis et tales conceptus sunt realiter et essentialiter distincti, ergo Alphonsus.

Quarto contra 3m corollarium: sapientiae divinae ut sic non repugnat non iustitia, ergo sapientia aliquo modo non est eadem cum iustitia, sed sapientiae divinae non repugnat simpliciter alius deus, ergo.
Contra tertiam conclusionem est propositio alia de causis qua dicitur quod intelligentia est substantia quae non dividitur, ergo non solus Deus.

Secundo
Philosophus II De anima Aristoteles, De anima, II, XXX
dicit intellectus simpliciter est impermixtus et immaterialis.
Tertio, contra primum corollarium est prima ratio in oppositum, quia quaelibet simplex est tam simplex quod ei correspondet unicus gradus et esse punctuale, ergo.

Quarto autoritate
Commentatoris 12o Metaphysicae dicentis quod
omnes formae
sunt
sunt
actu existentes in primo motore quae in potentia sunt in materia prima, Averroes, XXX
ergo in Deo non est omnimoda simplicitas.

Ad primum, negatur antecedens. Ad probationem, negatur maior et minor. Et ad probationem minoris, dico quod necesse esse repugnat creaturae non solum ex eo quod est ab alio, sed quia etiam libere contingenter producitur de nihilo et contingenter conservatur.
Ad secundum, conceditur assumptum et negatur quod illud sit impossibile, quia nec sequitur voluntatem divinam mutari vel esse mutabilem, aliter posset probari quod necessario omne futurum eveniret.

Ad tertium, negatur consequentia, quia tunc accidentia et lumen productum in medio aliquo modo non possent non esse. Secundo, dico quod licet non habeant materiam habent, tamen suum nihil quasi materiam et hoc sufficit.

Ad quartum, dici potest esse punctuale sibi correspondet et indivisibile, et negatur consequentia, ergo non est immensae perfectionis, quia simul est indivisibilis super simplex et immensus non habens in se formaliter latitudinem gradualem quamvis supereminenter contineat omnem perfectionis latitudinem.

Ad quintum, conceditur consequens quia quaelibet pars illius latitudinis potest poni in esse, et si infertur igitur potest poni inesse tota simul. Negatur consequentia, quia sicut etiam non sequitur quaelibet pars illius latitudinis potest poni inesse ergo possibile est poni inesse quamlibet eius partem, sic non sequitur quaelibet pars a continui a Sorte potest videri, ergo Sortes potest videre a continui quamlibet partem, nec sequitur quilibet gradus perfectionis possibilis potest poni inesse. Ergo possibile est quod ponatur inesse quilibet gradus perfectionis possibilis, licet consequens tenuerim probabiliter in
meo principio Supra vide
contra praedicatorem.

Ad sextum, negatur consequentia, quia deitas non se habet per modum speciei creatae personae nec divinae personae per modum individuorum, quia, licet duos homines sunt aliquod unum maius quam unus solus, tamen duae personae divinae non sunt maius quam una sola, ut dicit
Augustinus VIII De Trinitate, capitulo primo. Augustinus, De Trinitate, VIII, c. 1 (XXX)

Ad aliud, negatur consequentia, quia conclusio et corollaria intelliguntur de entitatibus realibus et non de complexe
significantibus.

Ad aliam, negatur antecedens quia ad illam, sequitur necesse esse non esse necesse esse. Et ad improbationem dico quod impossibile sequitur quodlibet et per consequens ex negativa sequitur affirmativa.

Ad primum contra secundam conclusionem dicitur quod Damascenus non loquitur de perfectionibus quod non realiter sint in Deo sed de nominibus quae de Deo praedicantur quorum aliqua secundum eum non praedicantur naturam, sed ea quae sunt circa naturam quod non est intelligendum quantum ad rem significatum, quia si res quae est sapientia divina non esset divina natura, sed aliquid circa naturam, non solum distingueretur formaliter, sed realiter et simpliciter quod est falsum. Sed intelligitur quo ad modum praedicandi quia talia nomina praedicantur de Deo denominative, et quae sic praesentatur de Deo quantum ad modum praedicandi non dicunt naturam, sed aliquid circa naturam. Haec est solutio Alphonsi.

Ad secundum, primo posset dici quod divisibiliter seu per divisibile distat angelo quia distat per totam perfectionem omnium creaturarum actualium et possibilium. Et negatur consequentia igitur partes quia illa divisibilitas non est deo intrinseca sed extrinseca.
Secundo posset dici hanc negando consequentiam distat indivisibiliter, ergo infinite minus quam quaecumque circa quia illud indivisibile per quid distat est immensum quia est Deus.

Ad aliud, negatur consequentia. Ratio est quia sapientia infinita et bonitas infinita in re sunt aliquid circumscripta omni ratione intellectus sapientia vero in communi et bonitas in communi non sic quia non sunt nisi quidam conceptus vel entia rationis. Et ad probationem quia infinitas non tollit rationem formalem alicuius conceditur, sed hoc non probat intentum, quia sapientia et bonitas in communi non solum praedicantur de sapientia et bonitate infinita, sed etiam de finita. De hoc vide Alphonsum.

Ad aliud contra tertium corollarium, concesso antecedente, negatur consequentia, nam non sequitur haec res diversimodae est quia possibile est quod propositum idem significatum una sit vera et alia falsa, non tamen sequitur quod significatum sit verum et falsum.
Ad aliud, conceditur consequens. Et ad improbationem, quia tunc obiectum unius, etc., conceditur. Et cum improbatur, quia Deus intelligit malum etc., conceditur, sed non sequitur quod infertur.

Secundo dico quod voluntas divina intelligit omnem malum quia intellectus divinus qui intelligit est formaliter voluntas divina, malum ergo est obiectum voluntatis, non ut volitum, sed ut cognitum et intellectum.
Tertio posset negari illa consequentia, voluntas divina et intellectus sunt idem, igitur quidquid intellectus intelligit voluntas vult.

Ad aliud, negatur maior et minor quia non oportet quod omnem illud quod necessitat ad conceptus distinctos sit conceptibiliter distinctum nisi velimus ab uti vocabulo, nec etiam perfectio divina necessitat ad distinctionem actuum diversorum ut assumit ratio.
Ad rationem contra tertium corollarium, negatur maior quia sapientia divina est omnis perfectio formaliter, et omne quod est melius esse quam non esse simpliciter sub bono intellectu.
Ad primam auctoritatem contra tertiam conclusionem, intelligentia est substantia quae non dividitur. Hoc est verum quantum ad partes naturae vel quantum ad durationem, quae est tota simul.

Ad aliam, dicitur quod intellectus est virtus simplex, id est, non organica. Hoc voluit Philosophus. Secundo dicitur simplex aliquo modo non simpliciter quia omnis creatura aliquo modo est composita et potentialitati subiecta.

Ad prima rationem in oppositum dicitur quod si antecedens intelligitur de simpliciter simplici est falsum. Et ad probationem dicitur quod non valet consequentia. Et si ultra inferretur anima non est simplex, igitur habet partes, consequentia negatur.

Ad aliud dicitur huiusmodi formas in primo motore esse in distinctas actu quia creatura in Deo non est aliud quam divina natura
penitus in distincta.
Ad alias rationes in oppositum patet solutio per dictam

Nunc de veritate seu proprietate, haec distinctio continet nona conclusiones. Prima quod solus Deus vere et proprie est quia eius essentia non novit praeteritum vel futurum. Hoc est non subest praeteritioni aut futuritioni, sicut cetera creata
Secunda conclusio: ideo dicit Deus semper fuit vel erit, ut intelligatur quod non incepit esse nec desinet.

Tertia conclusio: quod licet verba substantiva diversorum temporum dicantur de deo, scilicet fuit, erit, est, et erat, non tamen de Deo dicuntur quia esse divinum praeteritioni aut
subiectio
futuritioni subiaceat cum temporalis motus Deo repugnet, sed dicuntur ad denotandum Deum esse aeternitatem et permanentiae ipsius proprietatem.

Quarta conclusio: solius Dei essentia incommutabilis proprie dicitur quia nec mutatur nec mutari potest, omnis autem creatura mutari potest, Deus autem non nec loco nec tempore nec affectione, et ita sine sui mutatione cunctas condidit creaturas. Et per consequens solus Deus proprie habet immortalitatem, omnis autem creatura est mortalis ex sua natura, quia sua mutatio mors appellatur.

Quinta conclusio: Deus solus est vere ac proprie simplex, quia in eo nec partium nec accidentium sive formarum est diversitas vel vario modo sive multitudo. Omnis creatura est multiplex, quamvis spiritualis creatura respectu corporalis dicitur simplex, non tamen est vere simplex, quia in tali est diversitas accidentium sive formarum accidentalium, ut in animalibus humanis et angelis, nullum enim quod est vere simplex est mutabile.

Sexta conclusio quod anima respectu corporis simplex dicitur quia molae non diffunditur per
spatium saptium
loci, sed in uno quoque corpore est in toto tota et in qualibet eius parte tota.

Septima conclusio: quod licet Deus dicatur multipliciter, scilicet bonus iustus sapiens et magnus, tamen hoc non est propter diversitatem accidentium, sed propter multitudinem nominum quae, licet multa sint et diversa, unum tamen significant, scilicet naturam divinam.

Octava conclusio: quod proprie Deus non dicitur substantia quasi sit subiectum suae bonitatis vel alicuius accidentis, sicut substantia corporalis, quae ideo dicitur substantia quia subsistit et est multorum accidentium subiectum, sed Deus proprie et vere dicitur essentia.

Nona conclusio: Deus, ideo simplex dicitur quia ipse est quidquid habet excepto quod persona dicitur relative ad alteram, nec tamen una est altera, nam Pater habet Filium ad quem relative dicitur, et tamen Pater non est Filius, et Filius habet Patrem, nec tamen est Pater in quo vero ad semet ipsum dicitur non ad alteram, hoc est quod habet. Unde ipse Deus est unus et habet vitam et est ipse una vita nec aliud est habens et aliud quod habetur, sicut in ceteris rebus ubi semper sequitur aliqua distinctio.
